title: How long has Brexit been going on and what was the original Brexit date?
text:
The UK will be staying in the European Union a bit longer – but just how long has Brexit already taken? (Picture: Getty Images)

The UK’s departure date from the European Union has been delayed once again after EU members agreed to an extension until 31 January 2020.

EU Council leader Donald Tusk confirmed that the new delay will be a ‘flextension’ – meaning that the UK could leave sooner if a deal is ratified in that time.

It’s not the first time that the date for Brexit has been changed, of course, with the original departure date now looking very far in the past indeed.

But just when were the UK originally meant to leave – and how long has Brexit been going on?

Here’s what you need to know…

How long has Brexit been going on?

The referendum over whether the UK should remain in or leave the European Union took place on 23 June 2016.

The vote resulted in 16,101,241 votes to remain and 17,410,742 people voting to leave – or in percentage terms, 51.8 per cent voting leave and 48.1 per cent voting remain.

That means it’s been three years and four months since the original referendum.

Although the vote took place in June 2016, it was another nine months before then Prime Minister Theresa May triggered Article 50 – the start of the exit process for the UK to leave the bloc – which added even more months to the whole Brexit process.

What was the original Brexit date?

Theresa May originally negotiated a Brexit deal but it was rejected three times by Parliament (Picture: Getty Images)

The UK was originally supposed to leave the European Union at 11pm on 29 March this year.

The date was first set in stone after Theresa May triggered Article 50 on 29 March 2017 – with the negotiation period initially meant to last for two years.

However this was delayed after Mrs May was unable to get her original withdrawal agreement through Parliament, with Commons rejecting the deal three times.

The UK’s departure was initially delayed by just two weeks until 12 April to allow time for the deal to get through, but this ended in failure – leading to the EU offering the longer extension to 31 October.

The new extension gives the UK until 31 January 2020 to leave the EU, although if Boris Johnson’s new withdrawal deal were to be passed, the UK could leave on the first day of the month after this.

It was offered by the EU after Mr Johnson wrote to Donald Tusk to as for an extension as demanded by the Benn Act – the law passed by MPs in September to avoid the UK leaving the European Union with no deal.

The longer extension also paves the way for a potential general election, with Boris Johnson set to ask MPs on Monday to back his call for an election on 12 December.
description: Brexit has been delayed once again after the EU offered the UK a 'flextension' until 31 January 2020.
